Just by looking at your moon, I can tell you're in the southern hemisphere for that shot at the beginning. Looking at that moon, it's upside down from where I'M seeing it: In the northern Hemisphere.

If viewed from the southern hemisphere, the moon will appear upside down from how it appeared in the northern hemisphere. That's because of where you are on the Earth. From the southern hemisphere, you are basically facing upside down from where the moon is...

Why did you choose 3012 mirror tiles? Surely if you covered the moon with mirror tiles the same size as used in a conventional mirrorball (~1cm²), without scaling them up as you did, you'd probably get a much better discoball effect (from our perspective) from the moon's current distance than the one you were originally attempting to illustrate. Obviously you'd need billions (trillions?) of 1cm² mirror tiles, though, to cover the entire surface of the moon. Also depends on how large the reflection of the sun is on Earth from each mirror tile as to how bright it is. I guess the optimal size of the mirror tile would be one that is big enough to encapsulate and reflect the image of the entire sun (hence its full brightness) onto the Earth, rather than crop the sun's image to a large degree, although cropping the sun just enough to fill each square tile might offer the best compromise (and increase the number of rays and chance of intersecting Earth). Another optimisation would for the mirror tiles to be as thin as possible so as to increase the surface area of the reflective part of the tiles, although you could take this even further and change the square mirror tiles to polygons (nᵗʰ order geodesic sphere) to eliminate all gaps.

I think the one where the the disco ball is the same distance out as the actual moon is the most interesting.
Imagine if that had actually happened.
We wouldn't know about the moon.
What we would know is that occasionally people come out and say they saw a flash of light from the sky, and that there is a gigantic black circle in the sky which, for some reason, blocks out the sky.
Some researcher will point a telescope directly at it and notice that there is nothing there but stars. Albeit, small squares of different patches of stars which individually move over time.
Given a few years, someone will come up with the theory that there is a disco ball in the sky. And then they will test it. Then they will realize it is true. Its not some insane conspiracy, its actually what happened.
Then people will try to figure out why.
And since there is always a why, a before, people will come up with theories, and one of them will actually be plausible.
Then they refine it, and if you, from this universe, listen to the theory, it will be completely insane, since there isnt a disco ball in space, but it will make sense, and you will realize it could have happened.
And as far as they know, it did happen, millions of years ago when the planet formed.
When in reality, the truth is that our universe wanted to know what would happen, so they made the moon a disco ball.
This does not happen in our universe.
Imaginary scenarios don't exist, there is only the scenario where the big bang happened and every effect has a cause.
This is why we can trust science.
Because we aren't a theoretical scenario made real.
We can't be.

the moon is not a disco ball, Polaris the north (what we call) star is. Polaris is a small like sphere that hangs from/or hovers at the center of the firmament/dome, our enclosed flat circular world. The firmament/dome & polaris/sphere are made of a carbon/diamond material. Polaris is the only real sphere/planet like object in our sky/space underneath the firmament/dome. Polaris spins slowly spinning one full revolution every 24 hours. The stars you see at night are light being reflected off Polaris onto the firmament, polaris has imperfections on it's smooth surface and each imperfection creates the stars projected onto the firmament you see at night. The light reflected off the middle of Polaris to the top, turns clockwise on the firmament, & the light reflected from the middle to the bottom off polaris turn counter clockwise on the firmament, just like a disco ball. That's why in the northern hemisphere (inner circle, land inside the equator) the stars tuns clockwise. In the southern hemisphere (outer circle, land outside the equator) the stars turn counter clockwise. Also in the southern hemisphere they see the moon upside down, due to perception because the moon stays on the path of the equator. The Sun's circular path starts on the tropic of cancer, & then moves outward to the equator, on to the tropic of Capricorn, & continues it cycle back inward, repeating this infinitely. That's why we have different seasons over the flat circular  world.That it why the inner/north pole area has daylight, multiple days in a row because the sun is on it's smallest circle & cast light upon the entire circle for a few days. Each revolution of it's cycle takes 24 hours to complete. The moon makes a revolution/circle around the equator every 28 days, on our flat circular world. That is why we have 13 full moons in 364 days. The way we get the different phases of the moon, because the moon & sun travel at different speeds. The way we get lunar and solar eclipses is because the sun goes behind & in front of the moon. There is also water outside of the firmament, & in the water are bubbles that light up with frequencies caused by mother earth vibrating through the firmament. This could be what falling stars are, or it could be small pieces of the firmament which is made of carbon/diamond that reflects sunlights as it falls to the earth, & only the dark side of the plane/earth is able to see it as it falls.

Wouldn't the occasional visible reflection of the sun in the disco-ball Moon be tremendously bright? IRL some tiny fraction of the sunlight that hits the Moon goes on the hit Earth, but when a disco-ball reflection caught us, it would look as bright as the sun but about 0.1% of the angular area.

Another way to look at it is the albedo of the Moon has to be multiplied by some amount (x5 or so?) and those flashes have to be bright enough to average out to the appropriate amount. (The moon is made of pretty dark rock https://www.nasa.gov/sites/default/files/thumbnails/image/epicearthmoonstill.png)

The glass would have to be pretty transparent given the tiles are 10km thick, but optical fibre glass can manage it, and there is plenty of silicon up there to build it (but what about other required elements?).

The projected images of the sun from each mirror would be far larger than is shown at 1:00. The sun is not a point source, so each sunspot would diverge from the lunar mirrors at about 1/2 degree, making the spots at earth distance about 3300 km across.

With the tiles 100 km across, the brightness in the spot (a somewhat blurry image of the sun) would be (100/3300)^2 dimmer than direct sunlight, or about 1/1100.

But the diffuse, dim reflection of sunlight from the dark rough lunar surface is about 1/1,000,000 of sunlight, so the discoball moon would give flashes 1000X brighter than normal sunlight.

The angular rate of the moon's rotation is about 1/2 degree per hour (696 hours per orbit, 360 degrees), so the spots would move across a given point on earth in about an hour.

Vsause I enjoy your videos and while the What if the Moon Was a Disco Ball has lots of beautiful images you missed a chance to explain refraction and how it relates to how light or dark an object appears.Cover the surface of the disco ball moon with 1/2 inch mirrors  and we would see an image of the sun. Grind them up into a power and spread them over the surface and we see a softly glowing ball. We no longer see a coherent image because the light is now coming at us from all different angles. When a crater is made on the moon the material ejected from it starts out lightly colored and darkens over time.  Smoke can appear blue, then white, and even black as the particles clump together even though it's made of the same stuff. Show how a slender reed will reflect a small ripple but will let a small wave pass by without it bouncing off. Explain how Morpho Butterflies, bird feathers, and oil slicks refract their rainbow hues. This really deserves a follow up episode.﻿

@Mike Kingan It might not incinerate the Earth like a giant death ray, but light still produces heat, and what we are looking at in this video is a massive boost to the green house effect. Not only would the light reflected on earth get bounced back, it would continuously catch suns rays to throw back down to Earth. We wouldn't be burned alive per se, but things would get heated up pretty quick.

I just want to say that all these people saying this video was useless or whatever don't seem to really understand what science truly is. I don't know if these people watch Michael's videos for the satisfaction of knowing facts or what, but they clearly are missing the basis of scientific thought.

"What if" is the bread and butter of science. The hypothetical is what brought about some of the greatest changes in human thought. "What if people and apes evolved from a common ancestor?", "What if the Earth was round?". These questions were "useless" at the time, but brought about a revolution.

Science is not about fact, it is about the unknown. Intelligence is not about knowing facts that other people worked hard to find, it is about going out and finding the answers yourself.

I hope you'll happen to read this and take it into consideration.

This, however, does not offer near as much information. The first "disco moon" really sold me and looked really neat, but the other views after that seemed repetitive and redundant. I still gave it a thumbs up, but it needs to make us think a little more, just as several of his other videos have done. Although it was not up to par to his other content, it was still pretty neat. It was okay. Can't wait for more content, though! He'll make up for this soon enough.

For those saying "we need to put a mirror in space"

First, how do we get a mirror that's big enough to be seen by the naked eye on space without it breaking for the vibrations caused by the friction of the atmosphere?

Second, how do we protect it from the tons of space junk orbiting the planet?, even if a piece of iron the size of a baseball would hit a mirror the size of an stadium the damage in outer space would be huge because of the lack of friction, imagine thousands of them at bigger and smaller sizes

Third, how clear will the reflection be after it crosses the atmosphere? The is a reason why the Hubble and other telescopes are put in orbit and that is the atmosphere is not transparent, since it is obviously composed by matter made up of a different concentration of elements each one having absorption and reflection spectrums chases are we get a blurry image that would need to be filtered by a mechanism before or own eyes can see it clearly

Fourth, since it is not profitable nobody has done it yet, and nobody will
